author: Bridget Judd
title: Suicide survivors beating the black dog
text:
Suicide Call Back Service on 1300 659 467 Beyond Blue on 1300 22 46 36 Headspace on 1800 650 890 
Wracked with grief, she searched for support in the Ballarat community but struggled to find anyone who was willing to talk openly about suicide. 
It is an experience that galvanised her to form SOS: Survivors of Suicide, a bereavement support and suicide prevention group, designed to break down the barriers around depression and anxiety in regional Victoria. 
Each month, a handful of women affected by suicide meet in a modest yellow brick building in Ballarat for tea, cake and a chat. 
The initiative has given them an opportunity to talk about their experience in a non-clinical environment — an outlet Ms Steenhuis said had been ignored for too long. 
"How can we expect people to reach out for help and say they're not coping if we, as a community, can't even talk about it to each other?" she said. 
Through word of mouth, her idea has had a powerful impact on the community. 
"When survivors of suicide can comprehend what has happened and talk about it, there's this ripple effect that happens, and more people start talking," she said. 'We don't want people to go through what we have' 
One of those survivors is Rebecca Waight, who lost her husband to depression in 2015. 
Like Ms Steenhuis, Ms Waight's partner had not shown any signs he was struggling with his mental health. 
It is a commonality that prompted the duo to expand the initiative and take the conversation to a community that had never been asked to listen. External Link: Let's Talk 
It started out simply — by making their presence known. 
"We had a stall set up at a local event, and a bloke kept walking past and stopping to suss us out," Ms Waight said. 
"After a while, he built up the courage to approach us, and pulled an old photo out of his wallet. 
"It was of his best friend, who had committed suicide over 30 years ago [but] he wasn't just carrying that photo around with him every day, he was carrying that grief as well." 
Together, and with the support of a group of dedicated volunteers, the pair are now establishing a crisis and support centre in the Ballarat region. 
"We don't want people to go through what we went through," Ms Waight said. 
"Suicide is 100 per cent preventable. That's the issue, it is preventable, we just need to be able to talk about it." Let's Talk is Sam's legacy 
About 150 kilometres outside Ballarat, in Victoria's far south-west, is the tiny dairy farming town of Ellerslie. 
It has a population of about 250 people, but you would struggle to find a more close-knit community. 
So when Sam Fitzgibbon, a popular 21-year-old Country Fire Authority (CFA) volunteer took his own life last year, it sent shockwaves through the region. Photo: Sam Fitzgibbon (L), with his sister, father and mother, Jane. (Supplied: Jane Fitzgibbon) 
Unfortunately, it was not an isolated occurrence. 
Over the past 12 months, the regional shires of Corangamite, Warrnambool and Moyne — that take in Ellerslie — have recorded 16 suicides. 
It prompted Sam's mum, Jane to reach out to John Parkinson, a mental health manager at St John of God's Hospital in Warrnambool, to help put a halt to the harrowing statistic. 
"We started out by talking to the local football clubs about depression and [about] recognising the signs because there weren't other services coming out to our communities at that point," Ms Fitzgibbon said. 
Almost inexplicably, the initiative spread by word-of-mouth, leading to a powerful grassroots movement called Let's Talk. 
Its aim is just that — to get people talking about their mental health — and Mr Parkinson and Ms Fitzgibbon are now hosting forums across the region, in schools, sporting clubs and the local pubs. 
"Feeling anxious, feeling stressed, not feeling well — they are all the signs we need to be aware of," Mr Parkinson said. 
"We want the community to take responsibility for this." 
The pair is determined to take the conversation to as many towns across the region as are prepared to listen, and are currently working to encourage a uniform mental health curriculum in schools. 
"Our legacy for Sam, and others like Sam, is that any parent would do anything for their child," Ms Fitzgibbon said. 
"So Let's Talk is about trying to reduce the fact that this continues."
